author: jdhitsolutions
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

This is a follow-up issue to https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/15429 which has been closed. The Cmdet working group has agreed that a new cmdlet called `Get-TranscriptStatus` should be developed.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

The cmdlet should be scope and user-specific only. It should indicate if transcription is currently running and to what file. For security purposes the cmdlet should only return information for the current user.

comments.author: jdhitsolutions
comments.body: I have had some other thoughts on this. I think the proper name should be `Get-TranscriptStatus` since that is really the goal. Is a transcript running?  Personally, I'd also like to see a value indicating when the transcript started.

comments.author: kilasuit
comments.body: I looked into this ages ago and I couldn't get any info on the current transcript file from within PowerShell when it is started via the Reg Keys listed in [PowerShell loves the blue team](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/powershell/powershell-the-blue-team/) post, without using handle from sysinternals & as such I stopped going any further.

title: Add Get-TranscriptStatus cmdlet
